problem: In a circle of radius 10 units, three points A, B, and C are placed such that triangle ABC is equilateral. What is the maximum possible area of triangle ABC?
solution: The maximum area of an equilateral triangle inscribed in a circle occurs when each vertex touches the circle. The side length $s$ of the triangle can be found using the formula $s = \sqrt{3} \times r$, where $r$ is the radius of the circle. So, $s = \sqrt{3} \times 10$. The area $A$ of an equilateral triangle is $(\sqrt{3}/4) \times s^2$, substituting $s$ gives $A = (\sqrt{3}/4) \times (\sqrt{3} \times 10)^2 = 75 \times \sqrt{3}$ square units. \(\boxed{75\sqrt{3} }\)
